column5: Online Travel Aggregators (OTAs), digital aggregators for hotels, activities, and digital travel utilities
column13: Travel faces one of the highest disruption risks across all verticals, with AI collapsing the entire journey from inspiration to booking into single conversational flows. With minimal customer loyalty and heavy reliance on search channels that AI has disrupted, OTAs risk becoming invisible data suppliers. The industry's web-heavy model leaves brands without defensible owned channels as complex travel queries become single AI prompts.
column17: The rigid booking flow we’re used to… origin, destination, dates, and filters doesn’t have to exist in an AI world
column21: Head of Marketing, Global Travel App
column25: Users jump between suppliers; loyalty is fragmented across flights, hotels, and cars.
column29: Head of Marketing, Global Travel App
column33: Our first-party traveler data is what will make or break us in terms of how we monetize with AI.
column37: VP Strategy & Marketing, Global Travel App
column41: AI reshape planning and booking, exposing weak loyalty and fragile trust.
column49: High risk as AI compresses inspiration, search, and comparison into one flow.
column57: Travel is highly exposed as AI intermediates data and booking flows.
column65: Price and availability data are already aggregated by search aggregators. AI can extend this practice and reduce reliance on existing platforms. There are limited regulatory barriers on things like merchant transactions and licensing.
column69: Low customer relationship strength due to weak loyalty, higher paid traffic, and greater engagement on web.
column77:
Organic demand is moderate, with SEO and direct
playing a major role alongside paid search.
column85:
Loyalty is low to moderate. Repeat behavior exists
but is fragmented across flights, hotels, and cars,
with brand trust varying by product type.
column93: Engagement is spread across web and app, supported by social and display. Search aggregators are central to comparison and research.

column5: Mobile games across casual, mid-core, and social formats
column9: Roblox, Candy Crush, Monopoly Go, Pokemon Go, Royal Match
column13: Mobile gaming enjoys some protection from service disruption but relatively weak loyalty creates some vulnerability from discovery disruption. While AI cannot replicate gameplay or live operations, moderate retention and paid-heavy acquisition leave gaming exposed as discovery channels shift. App-native engagement provides defense, but without stronger retention mechanics, user acquisition costs may climb.
column17: AI is great for speeding up creative iterations, but it doesn't replace the actual game or the player experience—those come from years of development, IP, and live-ops.
column21: Product Marketing Director, Leading Gaming Publisher
column25: Compared to other industries, gaming has a lower risk of AI taking over the service, because the unique value is the proprietary pool of IP, player data, and communities that only publishers control.
column33: If I want direct, immediate access and visuals of the games, I'll just go to the App Store. ChatGPT will only send me links there, so the app stores remain the primary anchor.
column37: Product Marketing Director, Global Gaming Publisher
column41: Complex game creation and proprietary player data create defenses against AI service disruption, offsetting some vulnerability in discovery shifts.
column49: Moderate disruption due to exposure to paid search and social.
column57: While AI can generate creative assets (graphics, basic design), it cannot replicate the full game development pipeline or ongoing service and community management.
column65: Publishers hold proprietary gameplay and monetization data, which is essential to optimization.
column69: Low customer relationship strength due to weak loyalty and higher reliance on paid traffic.
column77: Established games benefit from well-known IP, app store rankings, and social buzz that drive organic installs. Newer games rely more heavily on paid acquisition, especially during launches.
column85: Retention rides on post-launch engagement (i.e., events, promos, new modes) and in-game personalization. Engaged cohorts remain throughout event cycles, while casual players churn between updates.
column93: Gameplay, spending, and engagement (push notifications, messaging) happen entirely in-app. Web presence is secondary for trailers, support, and community forums.

column5: Digital-first learning platforms, classroom support tools, and study-aid platforms
column13: Education faces the second-highest disruption risk as AI can deliver personalized lessons at near-zero cost. With moderate retention and heavy SEO reliance, pure content platforms are vulnerable while those with certifications maintain some defense. The shift from "searching to learn" to "AI teaches directly" threatens traditional online education models unless platforms emphasize credentials and human validation.
column17: Search has historically been our strongest channel, but we're seeing growing pressure as AI summaries start showing up even above paid results.
column21: Global Head of Marketing Strategy, Education App
column25: In education, where information is a commodity, LLMs can deliver personalized lessons at near-zero marginal cost.
column41: High exposure to AI disruption driven by both discovery and service disruption from replicable workflows and fewer content barriers.
column49: High disruption due to high exposure to organic channels and paid search.
column57:
AI can already create full course flows, practice materials, and quizzes. Certification is the only piece they cannot
yet replicate.
column65: Most learning content and knowledge domains are publicly available with no proprietary ownership.
column69: Customer relationship strength is moderate due to slightly lower loyalty and greater engagement on web-based platforms.
column77: Education queries drive steady stream of organic demand, supported by SEO and answer engine optimization (AEO) as well as higher education partnerships. Paid channels are used for supplemental growth.
column85:
Learners in certificate or cohort-based programs tend
to persist, aided by progress nudges and structured
deadlines. Casual learners drop off faster.
column93:
Apps are central for micro-learning, quizzes, and
reminders. Long videos and assignments still skew
web-first. Both app
and web play complementary roles in sustaining
engagement.

column9: CNN, BBC, Newsbreak, NYTimes, Reuters, Fox News
column13: News faces the highest disruption risk with AI summarizing stories in zero-click answers. Organic traffic has already fallen 26% as AI aggregates and summarizes content (Similarweb 2025). With weak loyalty and overwhelming web dependence, publishers must pivot to investigative depth and direct reader relationships through apps and newsletters or risk becoming invisible content suppliers to AI systems.
column17: When someone clicks from an ad and comes to our site, they're still highly likely to subscribe. But if they've already gotten the content from the LLM, they might not need more—they're less likely to convert.
column21: SVP Brand Marketing, Leading News Publisher
column25: Big events like elections, economic shifts, and breaking news are a big
column29: component of driving intent and organic traffic.
column33: Price and loyalty discounts also anchor retention, alongside brand trust and exclusive reporting.
column37: SVP Brand Marketing, Leading News Publisher
column41: High exposure to disruption as AI summarizes news and shifts discovery channel mix.
column49: Moderate disruption due to exposure to social, paid search, and organic search.
column57: AI already summarizes and curates news in zero-click answers and can deliver daily briefs that substitute for browsing a publisher site.
column65: Core content (i.e., headlines, summaries, historical articles) is widely available and crawlable. Proprietary archives and user data exist, but AI can answer many queries from public and partner sources. There are few active regulations today, so no rules prevent aggregation to answer queries.
column69: Strong loyalty anchors engagement, yet paid conversion and engagement primarily on web makes customer relationship thin.
column77: Organic pull comes from search, direct, and social sharing. Significant news cycles (i.e., elections, economic shifts, breaking news) drive spikes. Paid mostly amplifies subscription offers and boosts key stories.
column85: Retention is built on daily habits, brand trust, and subscription value (i.e., exclusive reporting, pricing) for core users, but casual readers don't form strong routines. Push and email notifications as well as price offers are used to sustain engagement and limit churn.
column93: Consumption remains web-first while apps used mainly by core subs. Newsletters and push notifications drive readers back to web for full articles.

column5: Digital retailers, online review platforms, and leasing platforms
column9: Carvana, Edmunds, CarGurus, Autotrader, Kelly's blue book
column13: Auto marketplaces face high disruption as AI aggregates listings and connects buyers directly to sellers. With the lowest relationship strength and heavy web dependence, pure lead-gen models risk disintermediation. Only those with proprietary inventory, dealer integrations, and real-time data feeds maintain defensibility as AI reshapes car shopping from browsing to conversational queries.
column17: Discovery for cars is very visual: Users want to see the listings, apply filters, and compare. AI guidance can help, but it doesn’t replace browsing.
column25: Apps are mainly for core subscribers, but the classified browsing journey remains dominated by desktop and mobile web.
column33: We're seeing less visibility on Google due to AI Overviews, but traffic still flows through search—car buyers want specifics, not summaries.
column41: Rising disruption threat as AI tools aggregate listings and connect buyers and sellers, but proprietary inventory remains a moat.
column49: Moderate disruption due to exposure to affiliates and paid search.
column57: AI can aggregate listings, summarize options, and connect buyers and sellers. Full handoff including verification and payment still depends on marketplace infrastructure.
column65: Used car marketplaces hold proprietary inventory feeds and financing integrations. New car data and dealer info is broadly public. There are no known regulations against AI listing and transacting used cars online.
column69: Customer relationships are limited by infrequent purchases and web-heavy engagement.
column77: Large share of traffic comes organically through direct visits, search, and SEO. Paid channels drive app installs and new users, but cost is high at first touchpoint.
column85: Retention is limited by long vehicle purchase cycles. Most users return only when actively in market, then drop off once vehicle purchase is complete.
column93: Consumption remains web-heavy as listings, filters, and dealer contact forms are optimized for web. App usage is limited.

column5: Digital-first marketplaces, re-commerce platforms, discount/deal platforms, and omni-channel retailers' digital storefronts
column9: Amazon, Temu, Shein, eBay, Etsy, Walmart
column13: Retail faces severe disruption as agentic commerce enables AI to handle shopping end-to-end. Despite moderate loyalty, heavy exposure to search channels and AI's ability to aggregate product data threaten direct relationships, signaling a potential future where retailers without unique inventory or fulfillment become commoditized suppliers in an AI-mediated marketplace.
column17: That page is not just for people like you, it is very specifically for you and your household… 100% personalized in almost every case, sooner rather than later.
column21: Head of Media, Global eCommerce Brand
column25: We are a business that's about 80 to 90% repeat business in a given month... but our trouble is mid-funnel, and that's why we spend a decent amount of money on the buyer side on promotions and life cycle.
column33: The bulk of our traffic is organic, meaning from organic social or just direct traffic that happens on its own - somewhere around 60-70%.
column37: Head of Media, Global eCommerce Brand
column41: From discovery to checkout, AI agents displace conventional online retail touchpoints.
column49: Product search shifts to AI agents, weakening retailer-owned channels.
column57: AI agents can handle shopping journeys end-to-end, reducing reliance on retailer sites.
column65: AI surfaces pricing, product, and reviews, pulling traffic away from owned platforms.
column69: Retail thrives on strong acquisition strength, yet struggles with loyalty and engagement on app platforms.
column77: Organic demand is strong, with direct traffic, branded search, and word-of-mouth making up the bulk of growth. Paid media plays a supporting role.
column85: Retention is moderate to strong. Repeat purchasing is common, but customers often have split loyalty and chase deals, creating steady churn pressure.
column93: Apps are strong for actual transactions, but web browsing is still important for product discovery, comparisons, and checking promotions.

column5: Digital-first wellness, fitness, mediation, nutrition, and workout-tracking applications
column13: Health and Fitness faces high disruption as AI can generate workout plans and wellness advice. With moderate loyalty and a good amount of traffic from disrupted channels, brands must differentiate through customization, validation, and by leveraging proprietary data. Those emphasizing human expertise, device integration, AI integrations, and clinical accuracy can defend against more generic AI content.
column17: App store discoverability is going to be at risk - people may just go straight to ChatGPT and never search the stores.
column25: Fitness is a textbook case for AI creation - the content is largely public... the counterweight is consumer trust with sensitive health data - established apps have the edge there.
column33: A lot of '101' coaching can be generated by AI - workout plans, reminders, tips - but the reason people stay is the trusted app experience, their data history, and how we handle privacy.
column41: Core discovery channels face AI disruption, but there's potential for AI-fueled retention moat built on trust and first-party data.
column49: High disruption due to exposure to organic channels and paid search.
column57: AI can auto-generate workouts and meal plans, adapt difficulty, and answer questions.
column65: Underlying knowledge (i.e., exercise, nutritional information) is public. Available data from public online sources allow AI to provide personalized workouts even without  proprietary data. User caution over sensitive health data may slow broad AI adoption.
column69: Strong in-app behavior contributes to moderate customer strength despite low loyalty and on/off usage.
column77: Category benefits from strong word-of-mouth and creator and social buzz. Brands with trusted expertise (i.e., tracking, coaching, programs) pull steady organic demand, with paid used to accelerate new features and seasonal launches.
column85: Habit loops, personalized plans, and progress visuals keep engaged cohorts active. Churn is episodic (i.e., injury, life events), leading to moderate retention.
column93: Core experience including tracking, coaching, and notifications lives in-app. Ongoing usage and monetization also happens almost entirely in app. Web plays supporting role for educational content and sign-ups.

column5: Mobile-first dating and matchmaking apps with direct consumer interactions
column13: Dating remains protected by its core function of creating real-world relationships. However, moderate loyalty and episodic usage create vulnerability. With moderate traffic from disrupted channels and users increasingly asking AI for relationship advice, platforms must may look to strengthen retention through community features and adjacent networks (i.e., BFF, professional) before AI reshapes discovery.
column17: People still rely on word-of-mouth and friends, but Gen Z is already starting to ask ChatGPT for relationship advice - and that share will only grow.
column21: Director, Product Marketing, Global Dating App
column25: Dating is an app-first category. Web is mostly FAQs. Installs and monetization are almost entirely mobile.
column29: Director, Product Marketing, Global dating app
column33: UGC and cultural moments on TikTok/IG reduce blended CPI. Great creative plus social proof is more effective than traditional upper-funnel buys.
column37: Director, Product Marketing, Global dating app
column41: Low overall AI disruption risk as core services are protected by service and data moats, even with moderate discovery disruption.
column49: Moderate disruption risk driven by high exosure to to paid search and organic channels.
column57: AI provides companionship and relationship advice, but can't replicate core service network of authentic users and social interactions.
column65: Dating apps hold proprietary, sensitive profile and behavioral data (i.e., swipes, chats) that are not publicly available and cannot be recreated.
column69: Network effects and in-app behavior reinforce moderate customer strength despite low loyalty due to on/off usage.
column77: Category is culturally top-of-mind and brand-led, so the large share of installs come from word-of-mouth and social buzz/network effects rather than paid.
column85: Users engage in recurring on/off cycles, but while active they're highly engaged due to daily swiping, messaging, and event-driven features. Subscription, boosts, and personalized prompts keep sessions frequent until life status changes.
column93: Matching, messaging, push notifications, and safety features are app-native. Virtually all traffic and monetization occur in-app, with web only used for FAQ and other nominal purposes.

column5: Consumer-facing AI/LLM assistants, chatbots, and content creation apps
column13: Gen AI platforms face unique positioning: They are the disruptors but face intense competition. With 40% traffic from vulnerable channels and episodic usage patterns, platforms must build stickiness through distribution partnerships and specialized use cases. Success depends on becoming indispensable infrastructure rather than novelty tools.
column17: Most of our growth is still organic... people see an answer link or a shared thread and try it themselves.
column25: We see a lot of 'multi-home' behavior the same user might ask us for research, then jump to another model for code.
column33: We're still leaning heavily on paid channels - affiliates and search are easiest way to scale quickly when you don't yet have default status with users. The challenge is it's fragile. If those paid channels shift, traffic is immediately impacted.
column41: Service disruption isn't applicable here, but there is high discovery disruption due to high exposure to affiliates and paid search.
column49: High disruption due to high exposure to affiliates and paid search.
column69: Moderate relationship strength is driven by high usage of paid for adoption, fragmented usage behavior, and intense competition.
column77: Category benefits from strong word-of-mouth, social buzz, and PR around new model features. Free tiers and "share this answer" links generate steady organic demand, with paid used to amplify launches.
column85: Usage is recurring but episodic. Many users spread activity across multiple GenAI apps. Habits form around specific use caes (i.e., summaries, drafting, research) while casual users churn faster.
column93: Chat, voice inputs, and notifications are largely in-app. Web remains important for longer sessions and desktop workflows.

column5: Digital-first sports betting, online casino apps, and skill-based real money based platforms
column9: Fan Duel, DraftKings, Betfair, Bet MGM, William Hill
column13: RMG remains insulated by regulatory barriers and real-time odds that AI cannot replicate. However, weak loyalty from promo-chasing creates vulnerability. With 35% traffic from disrupted channels and moderate retention, platforms must strengthen relationships through personalization and VIP programs before discovery channels shift further.
column17: It's an app business... almost all of [our customers] are going to be organic on any given day just based on the purchase frequency of the category... for us, brand trust is the number one factor.
column25: 50% of bets are live betting... the biggest barrier is the infrastructure to price markets in real time. It's illegal to place a bet for someone else, you must have a license
column33: For Casino & Sports betting, disruption risk is low - operators rely on proprietary models and fast-moving odds that AI can't easily replicate
column41: Regulatory, data, and workflow barriers limit AI disruption.
column49: Moderate disruption risk driven by mixed exposure to high disruption channels, mitigated by high share of organic traffic.
column57: Live betting requires continous real-time odds refresh, which AI can't currently replicate.
column65: Operators rely on proprietary first-party data models to generate betting odds. Such models and feeds are tightly controlled and inaccessible to AI.
column69: Moderate overall customer loyalty is pulled up by strong organic drivers and deep app engagement with customers
column77: Organic demand is strong, fueled by brand and direct search, plus major event-driven spikes that amplify demand.
column85: Loyalty is moderate as many players use multiple platforms and pursue short term promotions, driving churn despite strong brand presence.
column93: Apps dominate engagement once deposits are made, though web remains important for odds comparisons, registration, and checking promotions.

column5: Digital productivity, communication, and collaboration platforms
column13: Productivity tools face high disruption pressure as AI agents replicate workflows, but strong loyalty from deep integration buys time. With 40% traffic from vulnerable channels and strong retention scores, platforms must embed AI capabilities directly to maintain relevance as standalone AI threatens to absorb basic productivity functions.
column17: The goal is to make the experience as sticky as possible so people stay in their accounts and keep engaging.
column21: Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
column25: There are companies that have had big drops in traffic, but the traffic was lower quality to begin with... some are now seeing fewer, but much higher intent visitors coming from ChatGPT.
column29: Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
column33: I haven't seen a lot of successes where workflows are fully transformed into a chat interface. AI works best as a companion to existing interfaces, not a replacement.
column37: Head of Growth Marketing, Global productivity platform
column41: High risk of both discovery and service disruption driven by AI integration pressure on workflow offerings.
column49: High disruption as organic and paid search are heavily exposed to AI overviews.
column57: Core features are sticky today, but AI agents are rapdily learning to replicate workflows.
column65: Security reviews and integration hurdles slow adoption, but these are procedural, not structural barriers. As of today no regulatory shield to prevent AI disruption.
column69: Deep integration in daily workflows drives loyalty with strong organic acquistion strength.
column77: Organic acquistion is very strong, driven by network effects, referrals, and community-driven sharing.
column85: Retention is strong, driven by deep integration into users' daily workflows. Once embedded, tools become sticky and are used consistently.
column93: Engagement is very strong across web and desktop, with apps deeply embedded into workflows and daily use.

column5: Digital-first social networking, messaging, and content-sharing platforms
column9: Facebook, Whatsapp, Instagram, TikTok, Telegram, Snap, Pinterest, X, Reddit
column13: Social demonstrates resilience with strong user relationships. Network effects and real-world relationships create barriers AI can't easily breach. With habitual usage and reliance on mobile apps, social platforms can leverage AI for enhancement.
column17: Discovery is moving from big platforms to niche communities where CPMs are cheaper and engagement is higher.
column21: Retention Lead, Global Social Media App
column25: People want to be where others are already engaged. It's about finding those with the ability to spend and making them succesful on the platform.
column29: Retention Lead, Global Social Media App
column41: Discovery remains resilient due to high direct share and platform loyalty.
column49: Social discovery with limited exposure to channels that AI can aggregate.
column57: The real-world relationships and network effects are unique and can't easily be reproduced by AI.
column65: Proprietary engagement and relationship data stay within platforms, limiting AI's ability to replicate the service.
column69: Organic acquisition strength and high loyalty due to network effects and habitual engagement drive strong customer relationships.
column77: Organic demand is strong, fueled by network effects, community behaviors, and embedded usage across platform.
column85: Retention is high, anchored by daily usage platforms, habitual engagement, and network lock-in.
column93: Engagement is overwhelmingly app-led, with mobile as the dominant access point.

column5: Digital wallets, challenger banks, peer-to-peer payment platforms, trading and investing apps
column9: PayPal, Revolut, CashApp, Venmo, Credit Karma, Robinhood, Coinbase
column13: FinTech maintains a strong defensive position with proprietary data moats and regulatory shields. While AI can educate and compare, it cannot access bureau data or approve loans. With 71% retention and 81% app engagement, platforms can leverage unique data while selectively partnering with AI ecosystems to maintain visibility without losing control.
column17: AI isn't sending you ten options anymore. It's sending you one - and we need to be that one
column21: Director of Growth Market, Financial Services Comparison Platform
column25: An LLM can tell you the 10 best balance transfer cards, but it can't tell you how likely you are to be approved. We can.
column29: Director of Growth Market, Financial Services Comparison Platform
column41: Discovery disrupted as queries move to AI, but proprietary data and regulatory barriers remain a moat.
column49: Moderate risk as search shifts to AI and winner-takes-all answers.
column57: AI can rank and list products, as well as provide educational financial information.
column65: Proprietary bureau and lender data sit with major platforms, limiting AI replication.
column69: Strong acquisition strength and sustained loyalty reflect strong customer relationships.
column77: Organic demand is very strong, with most users arriving via search, credit score and report services, and brand familiarity. Paid traffic plays a smaller role compared to other verticals.
column85: Retention is strong, anchored by recurring use of credit scores, reports, and notifications that keep members engaged and returning regularly.
column93: Engagement is highly app-led, with many integrated into everyday financial management.

column5: Banking and consumer platforms supporting account management and personal finance
column9: Chase, Wells Fargo, Citi, HSBC, BBVA, Lloyds, Capital One
column13: Financial services enjoy maximum protection through regulatory moats and switching costs. With less than a third of discovery traffic vulnerable and strong retention, traditional banks face minimal AI threat. Core workflows require licenses and compliance AI cannot replicate. The opportunity lies in using AI to enhance personalization while maintaining trust and regulatory advantages that new entrants cannot match.
column17: Financial services will be behind other industries in agentic commerce - people still need to read terms, review details, and apply manually.
column21: Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
column25: Once customers set up direct deposit or bill pay, they're very unlikely to switch– retention is built into the way people use our products
column29: Global Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
column33: The majority of our acquisition spend is still on digital display and paid search, with TV and social making up a much smaller share
column37: Global Head of Digital Marketing Platforms, Leading Bank
column41: Stable against AI disruption, supported by regulatory, data moats, and low discovery disruption risk.
column49: Low disruption due to low exposure to organic channels.
column57: AI can offer financial advice and transactional tools, but can't replicate core products (i.e., mortgages, accounts) that involve regulated workflows and human verification.
column65: Banks' proprietary datasets of transaction history across millions of users ensure a high moat for personalization and product recommendations.
column69: Customer relationships are reinforced by trust, but engagement is primarily on web.
column77:
Life-stage triggers (i.e., buying a home, starting
college) drive high-intent organic demand. Large
banks' trust and domain authority keep them
prominent in organic results.
column85:
Switching costs keep churn low. Points and rewards reinforce
retention.
column93:
Apps are increasingly used for ongoing engagement like daily
banking, but web is still central. 
Web also plays secondary role for research and sign-ups.

column5: OTT video and audio platforms, digital live-streaming services
column9: YouTube, Spotify, Netflix, Amazon Prime, Disney, Max, Soundcloud, Apple Music, JioHotstar, Gaana
column13: Media and Streaming platforms benefit from content rights and licensing barriers AI can't breach. With strong retention and subscription models, they face limited disruption. While AI can recommend content, it can't access proprietary content libraries. The opportunity is using AI to enhance personalization and discovery while maintaining exclusive content as the ultimate moat.
column17: The traditional entry points of SEO and app stores are exposed - AI can sit on top and redirect that traffic.
column21: Head of Marketing, Global Streaming App
column25: Retention is built on content access and rights, not just marketing spend.
column29: Head of Marketing, Global Streaming App
column41: AI disrupts discovery but faces rights and licensing barriers.
column49: High exposure as AI intermediates search, recommendations, and engagement.
column57: AI can replicate recommendations and search, but licensing and production remain protected.
column65: Strict copyright and licensing regimes prevent AI from replicating, training on, or distributing protected media content, keeping disruption risk low.
column69: Strong loyalty supported by recurring engagment and higher app-led engagement leading to strong customer relationships.
column77: Organic demand is strong for initial installs, but performance marketing is essential to drive paid conversions and sustain growth.
column85: Loyalty is strong, supported by subscription models and recurring engagement features that encourage long-term use.
column93: Engagement spans multiple platforms, with mobile apps at the core, complemented by web and TV apps, ensuring access across devices.

column5: Digital-first consumer apps for ride-hailing, food delivery, grocery delivery, and QSRs
column9: Uber, Doordash, Lyft, Resy, Instacart, McDonalds, Starbucks, TaskRabbit
column13: On-demand services remain protected by real-world logistics AI cannot replicate. Relatively strong retention and proprietary merchant/courier networks means platforms face limited disruption. While AI may handle ordering, fulfillment requires physical infrastructure. The opportunity is preparing for agentic reorders while strengthening in-app discovery and cross-category expansion.
column17: Most of conversion today comes from promotions, but you can't offer a promo inside an LLM answer. Over time, conversion will depend more on brand trust, and eventually agentic commerce will take hold.
column21: Head of Marketing Strategy, Global Food Delivery App
column25: AI can help people decide what to order, but they can't pick up the food. Even if an assistant places the order, it still runs on our network with data-merchant integrations, logistics, fraud, and customer care.
column29: Head of Marketing Strategy, Global Food Delivery App
column33: Compared with digital-only categories, on-demand has lower takeover risk from AI because the value sits in proprietary merchant/courier networks and transaction data.
column41: Real-time proprietary data and logistics protect service, while dependence on social and search creates moderate discovery disruption.
column49: Moderate disruption due to exposure to social, paid search, and organic search.
column57: End-to-end service lies within real-world logistics and merchant networks. AI can aid decisions but can't complete deliveries.
column65: On-demand platforms hold proprietary transaction and logistics data. AI lacks access to replicate these datasets.
column69: Customer ties anchored in convenience and app-first use, despite lower loyalty.
column77: Immediate, high-intent needs plus strong brand awareness and dense local coverage drive a large share of organic installs. Word-of-mouth and partnerships with restaurants and retailers reinforce pull.
column85: Habit and convenience anchor repeat use. Subscriptions, personalized promos, and saved favorites keep cohorts active. Deal-seeking behavior creates some churn pressure.
column93: Ordering, live tracking, support, substitutions, and tipping are all app-native. Web has essential functionality and FAQ, but ongoing engagement and monetization are in-app.

column5: Digital selling Car and 2W OEMs which have significant digital presence
column9: Tesla, Rivian, Polestar, Mercedes Benz, BMW, Mazda, OLA Electric
column13: Auto OEMs maintain strong position through brand equity and dealer networks. With 60% retention and minimal AI disruption risk, luxury brands especially remain resilient. While AI can assist configuration, high-value purchases require in-person validation. The opportunity is enhancing digital tools while preserving the aspirational brand experience that AI can't commoditize.
column17: AI can replicate things like configurators or trade-in calculators, but those are already digital. The bigger question is whether people will trust it for a $50,000 purchase.
column25: Discovery is already moving in-app. TikTok and Autotrader are embedding pricing, trade-ins, and financing directly inside the platform.
column41: Discovery and service face moderate disruption as AI reshapes journeys.
column49: Product search shifts to AI, weakening retailer-owned channels.
column57: Dealer tools like configurators and trade-ins are already digitized, so AI adds little disruption. Strong need for in-person experience in the industry.
column65: Fragmented data across OEMs, dealers, and third parties limit AI reach.
column69: Organic pull and retention are strong, yet dependence on web-based engagement remains high.
column77: Organic demand is strong, supported by brand equity, direct traffic, and word-of-mouth. A significant share of customers arrive without heavy reliance on paid.
column85: Retention is healthy, anchored by leasing and financing cycles that create natural repeat behavior. Brand trust and aspiration further reinforce loyalty.
column93: Automotive engagement remains centered on OEM sites, configurators, and dealer interactions. App-based traffic is limited, with digital touchpoints still largely web-driven.
